Why yes, Tristan, I've dabbled with changing the tiles using Editor.exe. 
That particular experiment resulted in the pillars in the TevFifty and the 
chakrams-for-rocks found in the group filespace. Everything else turned out 
just too weird to use.

I have only one problem with your story, Trahern, and it isn't that you 
included me in it. Far from that, I welcome people to use me in a story, 
even if it is as a "less interesting" character, "devoted to study" (blech). 
The dilemma lies in my name. It is spelled correctly once, at the very 
beginning, and is then disfigured by a spurious 'l' for the remainder of the 
tale. "Telvildo" is not a name; it's a travesty. I am Tevildo. Not Tevildo 
Dronnor, for that matter... I have no surname. If anything, write it like 
this:

     "Greetings," he said, sitting down opposite the elf by the campfire.
     The hooded face remained lowered, staring into the flames.
     "My name is Tevildo," he said, trying to deepen his voice and sound 
impassive, but at the same time remain friendly enough to spark 
conversation. They would be working together for some time. "Otherwise known 
as the Prince of Cats."
     The elf arced an eyebrow, but refrained from making comment.

Or:

     "Greetings," he said, sitting down opposite the elf by the campfire.
     The hooded face remained lowered, staring into the flames.
     "The mage?" came a strange voice from the hood. It was a softer tone, 
it sounded almost feminine, but Tevildo had had experience with elves 
before. This one was male, although there were many who would not have known 
such.
     "Yes," he said.
     "Trahern Stombackh Faiyne," the elf said, lifting his head from the 
fire. He pulled the hood back from his head to reveal his elven features. 
They were quite noticeable from a human's, of course. The long pointed ears, 
the chiseled jawbones, long grey hair, and greyish eyes that all of the 
lios-alfar seemed to have. What caught his attention was the face paint. 
Under his left eye, above his right, across both cheeks and temples, and the 
base of his left jaw were patterns of black and dark green.
     "Or Trahern, for short. You have waited for some time now, wanting to 
watch and observe before moving forward. I assume bad experiences in the 
past, yes?"
     "Nothing I could not handle," he replied. "My name is Tevildo." He 
tried to deepen his voice and sound impassive, while remaining friendly 
enough to spark conversation. They would be working together for some time.
     "Just...Tevildo?" The elf seemed confused.
     "Er, yes. Is that a problem?"
     The elf was suddenly on his feet, without appearing to have moved, eyes 
ablaze. "Have you no loyalty to your clan?" he exploded. "No sense of 
obligation to your family's honour? Does your ancestry mean nothing to you?"
     Tevildo thought this over. "No, not really," he finally admitted.
     Trahern sat down again, apparently mollified. "Oh," he said, and lapsed 
back into silence.

I'm just teasing, of course, but if there's one thing I can't stand it's 
people mangling my name. There's a lot of history and lore behind it, in 
real life as well as in story, and it's one of my most prized possessions. 
So please watch the spelling, and don't tack anything extra onto it. Prince 
of Cats is fine, as it is the equivalent of Tevildo and has been attached to 
the name since the fifth century.  Beyond that... no extras, please; no 
onion rings, no side of fries, no choice of beverage, and no Dronnor.

In actuality, I'm really glad you wrote this, and I urge you to continue it. 
The four of us against a powerhouse like Jakarta and his empire... I'd say 
he doesn't stand a chance. That is, if I'm allowed my basic spells to lay 
waste to his demonic hordes. There's a great potential here... will Tevildo 
grow into an Archmage? Will Bjorn prove sneakier than Jakarta's man Ajax? 
How will the brute force of Hightower match up against the power Lord Kelvin 
has borrowed from the Children of the Sun? The (possibly) immortal elf 
Trahern and Molokai the Old--who's older? Inquiring minds want to know!

I thought that my fanfic about Torvald would be the first Gladiator fanfic 
ever--guess I was wrong. It would have been finished long ago, but I 
couldn't decide whether I wanted companion scenarios, and if I did then I'd 
have to hold off writing so that the two would gibe. At this point, I think 
the scenarios would be superfluous, so when it does appear it will be prose 
alone.

This idea of writing fanfics for Gladiator brings up an interesting question 
of canon and fanon. An article I was reading a couple of days ago defined 
the two: canon is material established in the official "corpus": here the 
basic Gladiator set of 1 through 45, plus the handful of multi-team 
scenarios around 300 that really only mention Lord Malrac, plus a couple 
fragmentary scenarios from Beyond Freedom. Not too much to work from. It 
could be proposed that since the Tryxian Chronicles appear on the website, 
that they are endorsed as part of the official story line. God, I hope not. 
"Fanon" is what is created by the fans, a substitute or supporting body 
that, while not authoritative, adds to the depth and enjoyability. This 
would be all the fan-created stuff, both in stories and scenarios. I think, 
if we are to be creating new material, then perhaps our fanon should become 
part of the canon itself. After all, if the plans for the new scenario 
editor work out, then in a way we are the new Forgotten Sages, and as such 
would have some creative control over the Gladiator stuff in general. What I 
want to know is why we need a new editor. The only problems I have with the 
old two is that I can't use a wide range of punctuation in the text. Period, 
comma, apostrophe. That's it. Enough to drive a writer insane, I tell you... 
If I could access my oh-so-beloved quotation marks, exclamation points, 
question marks, parentheses, dashes, colons, semicolons, and ampersands, 
then I'd be happier than a pig in slop. Everything else I can do, and 
everyone on the list can figure it out with a little practice. Now, if some 
fella was talking of applying his coding skills to the completion of Beyond 
Freedom, I'd be behind him one hundred percent. I'd help out, to the best of 
my ability, and plug away at new scenario design as fast as my 
keyboard-ravaged fingers could manage. Not to rain on anyone's parade, but 
it seems to me that people are getting ready to invest a whole hell of a lot 
of time to a slightly unnecessary and probably unpopular project, when it is 
in our grasp to create something as nifty and stable as Warcraft II. So: if 
we have coders and time and space and permission, why are we not going for 
the gold?

Sorry about the verbosity, folks, but I just finished reading Dalton 
Trumbo's "Johnny Got His Gun"... and being unwilling to communicate is just 
as bad as being unable to communicate, like the poor guy in the story... So 
write, shout, spray-paint your tag all over the city, bludgeon a politician 
in front of his horrified colleagues, or otherwise raise a ruckus and make 
yourself heard. If you don't have anything to say that's worth beating a 
politician over, then chances are you're also a politician. Ta.
     -Tevildo, Still Riding his Literary Intoxication.
